Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.check

Class Check<T,​E extends Exception>

java.lang.Object
nl.naturalis.common.check.Check<T,​E>
Type Parameters:
T - The type of the object being checked
E - The type of exception thrown if a test fails
public abstract class Check<T,​E extends Exception>
extends Object
Facilitates precondition checking. For example: 

 this.numChairs = Check.that(numChairs).is(gt(), 0).is(lte(), 10).is(even()).ok();

Common checks

The CommonChecks class provides a grab bag of common checks for arguments. These are already associated with short, informative error messages, so you don't have to invent them yourself. For example: 

 Check.that(numChairs, "numChairs").is(gt(), 0);
 // Auto-generated error message: "numChairs must be > 0 (was -3)"

Checking argument properties

A Check object lets you check not just arguments but also argument properties. For example: 
 Check.notNull(name, "name").has(String::length, "length", gte(), 10);
 Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getAge, "age", lt(), 50);
 Check.notNull(employees, "emps").has(Collection::size, "size", gte(), 100);

The CommonGetters class defines some common getters which, again, are already associated with the name of the property they expose: 

 Check.notNull(employees, "emps").has(size(), gte(), 100);
 // Auto-generated error message: "emps.size() must be >= 100 (was 42)"

Lambdas

Checks are done via the various is(...) and has(...) methods. These methods are overloaded to take either a Predicate or an IntPredicate. This is not a problem when passing them a method reference or a check from the CommonChecks class. When passing a lambda, however, the compiler will be unable to decide whether it is dealing with a Predicate or an IntPredicate - an unfortunate side effect of the combination of type erasure and auto-boxing. This will result in a compiler error like The method is(Predicate<String>) is ambigious for the type Check<String, IllegalArgumentException>: 

 // Won't compile even though it's clear this can't be an IntPredicate:
 Check.that(fullName).is(s -> s.charAt(0) == 'A');

To resolve this, simply specify the type of the lambda parameter: 

 Check.that(fullName).is((String s) -> s.charAt(0) == 'A');

Alternatively, you can use the asObj and asInt utility methods: 

 Check.that(numChairs).is(asInt(x -> x <= 10)); // IntPredicate
 Check.that(numChairs).is(asObj(x -> x <= 10)); // Predicate<Integer>

Or, as another alternative, every Predicate can also be written as a Relation: 

 Check.that(fullName).has(s -> s.charAt(0), eq(), 'A');

Changing the Exception type

By default an IllegalArgumentException is thrown if an argument fails to pass a test. This can be customized through the static factory methods. For example: 

 this.query = Check.with(InvalidQueryException::new, query, "query")
  .has(Query::getFrom, "from", nullOr(), 0)
  .has(Query::getSize, "size", gte(), 10)
  .has(Query::getSize, "size", lte(), 10000)
  .ok();
Author:
Ayco Holleman

    • catching

      public static <U,​ V,​ X extends Exception> Check<V,​X> catching​(Function<String,​X> excFactory, U arg, ThrowingFunction<U,​V,​?> argTransformer, String argName) throws X extends Exception
      Static factory method. The catching(...) factory methods are different from the other factory methods in that the returned Check object works on some transformation on the argument, rather than the argument itself. If the transformation is successful, you get back a regular Check object that you can use to do additional checks on the transformed value (not the original argument). If it is the transformation itself that you care about, you can also simply call ok() immediately. If the transformation function throws an exception, the exception message is passed on to the same exception factory that is also used for regular checks on the Check object (thus, in effect, converting the original exception to an exception of your choosing).

      Examples 

       int i = Check.catching(System.getEnv("THREAD_COUNT"), Integer::valueOf).ok();
 int i = Check.catching(System.getEnv("THREAD_COUNT", Integer::valueOf)
    .is(gt(), 0)
    .is(lte(), 4)
    .ok();
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the argument
      V - The type of the converted argument
      X - The type of Exception thrown if the argument fails to pass a test, or if the argument conversion fails
      Parameters:
      excFactory - A Function that will produce the exception if a test fails, or if the argument conversion fails. The Function will be passed a String (the error message) and must return the Exception to be thrown.
      arg - The argument
      argTransformer - A function that takes the argument and transforms it into the value that you want to test and work with
      argName - The argument name
      Returns:
      A new Check object
      Throws:
      X - If the converted argument fails to pass a test, or if the argument conversion fails

    • argName

      public String argName()
      Returns the name of the argument being tested.

    • is

      public Check<T,​E> is​(Predicate<T> test) throws E extends Exception
      Submits the argument to the specified test. This method is especially useful when using the (statically imported) tests in the CommonChecks class, as they have predefined, informative error messages associated with them.
      Parameters:
      test - The test
      Returns:
      This Check object
      Throws:
      E - If the test fails

    • is

      public <U> Check<T,​E> is​(Relation<T,​U> relation, U relateTo) throws E extends Exception
      Verifies that the specified relation exists between the argument and some other value. This method is especially useful when using the (statically imported) tests in thw CommonChecks class, as they have predefined, informative error messages associated with them.
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the object of the relationship
      Parameters:
      relation - The relation to verify between the argument and the specified value ( relateTo)
      relateTo - The object of the relationship
      Returns:
      This Check object
      Throws:
      E - If the test fails

    • given

      public Check<T,​E> given​(boolean... conditions) throws E extends Exception
      Imposes some extra preconditions that may or may not be related to the argument being checked by this instance. Lazy but practical. For example a precondition check for a typical OutputStream.write(b, off, len) implementation might look like: 

       write(byte[] b, int off, int len) {
   Check.notNull(b, "b").has(length(), gte(), off + len).given(off >= 0, len >= 0);
   // ...
 }
      Parameters:
      conditions - The conditions to evaluate
      Returns:
      This Check object
      Throws:
      E - If any of the conditions evaluate to false

    • given

      public Check<T,​E> given​(String message, boolean... conditions) throws E extends Exception
      Imposes some extra preconditions that may or may not be related to the argument being checked by this instance. Lazy but practical. For example a precondition check for a typical OutputStream.write(b, off, len) implementation might look like: 

       write(byte[] b, int off, int len) {
   Check.notNull(b, "b")
     .has(length(), gte(), off + len)
     .given("No can do buddy: check condition %d", off >= 0, len >= 0);
   // ...
 }
      Parameters:
      message - A custom message that may (but does not have to) contain one %d message argument. The message argument is substituted with the one-based number of the first condition that failed.
      conditions - The conditions to evaluate
      Returns:
      This Check object
      Throws:
      E - If any of the conditions evaluate to false

    • ok

      public abstract T ok()
      Returns the argument being tested. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. For example: 
       int age = Check.notNull(employee, "employee").has(Employee::getAge, "age", lt(), 50).ok().getAge();
      Returns:
      The argument

    • ok

      public <U,​ F extends Throwable> U ok​(ThrowingFunction<T,​U,​F> transformer) throws F extends Throwable
      Passes the argument to the specified Function and returns the value it computes. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the returned value
      Parameters:
      transformer - A Function that transforms the argument into some other value
      Returns:
      The value computed by the Function
      Throws:
      F - The exception potentially thrown by the Function

    • then

      public <F extends Throwable> void then​(ThrowingConsumer<T,​F> consumer) throws F extends Throwable
      Passes the validated argument to a Consumer to be processed safely. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
      Parameters:
      consumer - The Consumer
      Throws:
      F extends Throwable

    • intValue

      public abstract int intValue() throws E extends Exception
      Returns the argument being tested as an int. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks. If the argument being tested actually is an int (rather than an Integer), this method saves the cost of a boxing-unboxing round trip incurred by ok().
      Returns:
      The argument cast or converted to an int
      Throws:
      E extends Exception
      See Also:
      NumberMethods.fitsInto(Number, Class)

    • intValue

      public <U> U intValue​(IntFunction<U> transformer) throws E extends Exception
      Passes the validated argument to the specified Function and returns the value computed by the Function. To be used as the last call after a chain of checks.
      Parameters:
      transformer - An IntFunction that transforms the argument into some other value
      Throws:
      E extends Exception
